statements.text: The disappearance of Dr. Harland Bishop was reported at 7:30 a.m. on Tuesday, August 17, by the museum's assistant curator.
Dr. Bishop, a renowned archaeologist, was last seen leaving the Restoration Wing at around 10:00 p.m. on Monday night.
A priceless artifact known as the Emerald Sphinx was found missing from the museum's secure vault.
Security logs indicate the vault was accessed using Dr. Bishop's ID card at 10:17 p.m. Monday.
The vault requires both an ID card and a numeric code to open.
Only three people knew the numeric code: Dr. Bishop, the museum director, and the chief of security.
Dr. Bishop had been in a heated dispute with the museum director over the allocation of research funds.
Ms. Lenora Clay, the assistant curator, claimed she heard a loud bang from the Restoration Wing around 10:30 p.m.
The janitor, Alan Deeks, stated he saw a shadowy figure carrying something bulky wrapped in canvas toward the back exit at approximately 11:00 p.m.
A small trail of dried blood was discovered near the entrance to the Restoration Wing.
Security cameras covering the Restoration Wing went offline between 10:15 p.m. and 11:05 p.m. due to a 'network issue.'
A maintenance record shows that the camera server was scheduled for inspection the following morning, but no work order was filed for Monday night.
The chief of security, Maurice Penn, was not present at the museum that night, citing illness.
Mr. Penn's neighbor reported seeing him loading a heavy duffel bag into his car late Monday night.
Dr. Bishop's car was found still parked in the museum lot.
Police found a burner phone in a trash bin outside the museum, containing texts arranging a meetup at 1:00 a.m. near Lake Verity.
The phone was traced to a prepaid account purchased by someone using a fake name and address.
A witness jogging by Lake Verity reported seeing two people arguing near the pier around 1:10 a.m.
Divers recovered a blood-stained lab coat and a museum ID badge belonging to Dr. Bishop from the lake.
Fingerprint analysis showed that the ID badge had been wiped clean, except for one partial print belonging to Ms. Clay.
Ms. Clay denied ever touching Dr. Bishop's badge and said she hadn't been near the lake.
Mr. Deeks, the janitor, has a prior conviction for grand theft auto but has worked at the museum for six years without incident.
The museum director, Edmund Harrick, was attending a gala in Boston the night of the disappearance, with several witnesses confirming his presence.
Records show that Mr. Penn accessed the museum's security override system remotely at 10:10 p.m.
An anonymous email was sent to the museum director at 2:00 a.m. Tuesday morning, demanding $3 million in exchange for the safe return of the Emerald Sphinx.
Police traced the email's origin to a public library terminal in East Barrow, five miles from Lake Verity.
A lockpick set was found in the museum's HVAC vent system during a routine sweep the next morning.
The security team noted that the HVAC access panel near the Restoration Wing had fresh tool marks.
Dr. Bishop had been scheduled to give a press conference on Tuesday to announce the upcoming exhibition of the Emerald Sphinx.

entities.name: Edmund Harrick (museum director) [Mr. Harrick, museum director]
HVAC Vent System [HVAC vent system, HVAC access panel]
Public Library in East Barrow [public library terminal in East Barrow]
Museum Gala in Boston [gala in Boston]
